title: open redirect in rfc6749

activities.message: The last news I got from one of the WG guy is that they will probably need to add an RFC errata to the rfc6749 spec and for the short term add an advisory to http://oauth.net/advisories/ .
activities.markdown_message: The last news I got from one of the WG guy is that they will probably need to add an RFC errata to the rfc6749 spec and for the short term add an advisory to http://oauth.net/advisories/ .

activities.message: update: I have started to notify OAuth providers in order to make them aware of this issue
activities.markdown_message: update: I have started to notify OAuth providers in order to make them aware of this issue

activities.message:
@asanso - Interesting finding. This is on the edge of what we normally consider eligible under the program. In many contexts, open redirects are relatively benign. Two immediate questions on my mind:

- Has there been any update on a formal modification to the RFC or an advisory from the WG?
- Have you identified any provider implementations where the impact went beyond an open redirect? (e.g., leaking tokens or other identifiers through the redirect referrer)

Thanks,
Alex
activities.markdown_message:
@asanso - Interesting finding. This is on the edge of what we normally consider eligible under the program. In many contexts, open redirects are relatively benign. Two immediate questions on my mind:

  • Has there been any update on a formal modification to the RFC or an advisory from the WG?
  • Have you identified any provider implementations where the impact went beyond an open redirect? (e.g., leaking tokens or other identifiers through the redirect referrer)

Thanks,
Alex

activities.message:
@arice. Thanks a lot for reviewing it.
I agree the open redirect are kind of borderline, but at the end of the days isn't [OWASP 10](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2010-A10-Unvalidated_Redirects_and_Forwards) :)?

Trying to answer your questions:

1)  The (relative long) discussion in the [IETF mailing list](http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/oauth/current/msg13367.html) seems to eventually acknowledge the issue. I also been in touch privately with some member of the OAuth working group. This is going to be discussed in the next IETF face to face meeting in November and might end up on producing an errata (I will keep you updated) and an advisory on the OAuth webiste (http://oauth.net/). As a side note the IETF process aren't the quickest one :)

2)  Yes, I have done and got also bounties from big Providers for it (e.g. http://intothesymmetry.blogspot.ie/2014/04/oauth-2-how-i-have-hacked-facebook.html).
There is a big difference though. The issues as the one I found above are substantially different.  This is because those kind of attack are based on implementation mistakes (e.g. path traversal on redirect uri patter matching) and many other people in the wild have found many of those vulnerabilities as an outcome of implementation mistakes (should you be interested I can point out many).  
The issue I report here is a bit different though. The impact might  be lower (namely "only" open redirect rahter than tokens hijacking) but it is a specification issue (IMHO).
Namely if a providers tries to implement the spec verbatim ends up having an open redirect (unless deviate from the spec). That is why an errata seems to be appropriate.
Just to be more clear a token hijacking isn't possible here because the "attack" targets the  [Error Response](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.1.2.1) section where tokens are not yet produced

@arice. Thanks a lot for reviewing it.
I agree the open redirect are kind of borderline, but at the end of the days isn't OWASP 10 :)?

Trying to answer your questions:

1) The (relative long) discussion in the IETF mailing list seems to eventually acknowledge the issue. I also been in touch privately with some member of the OAuth working group. As a side note the IETF process aren't the quickest one :)

2) Yes, I have done and got also bounties from big Providers for it (e.g. http://intothesymmetry.blogspot.ie/2014/04/oauth-2-how-i-have-hacked-facebook.html).
There is a big difference though. The issues as the one I found above are substantially different. This is because those kind of attack are based on implementation mistakes (e.g. path traversal on redirect uri patter matching) and many other people in the wild have found many of those vulnerabilities as an outcome of implementation mistakes (should you be interested I can point out many).

The issue I report here is a bit different though. The impact might be lower (namely "only" open redirect rahter than tokens hijacking) but it is a specification issue (IMHO).
Namely if a providers tries to implement the spec verbatim ends up having an open redirect (unless deviate from the spec). That is why an errata seems to be appropriate.
Just to be more clear a token hijacking isn't possible here because the "attack" targets the Error Response section where tokens are not yet produced

activities.message:
just little update. I just read an article that actually used this kind of open redirect (chained with another issue but still :))
Here is the link http://andrisatteka.blogspot.ch/2014/09/how-microsoft-is-giving-your-data-to.html

Here is the link http://andrisatteka.blogspot.ch/2014/09/how-microsoft-is-giving-your-data-to.html

activities.message:
couple of little updates:

- this very issue has been discussed in the IETF 91 meeting , see bottom part of http://www.ietf.org/proceedings/91/minutes/minutes-91-oauth. The outcome seems  to be that some kind of security write up should cover this point.
- I have been contacting OAuth providers and some of that changed the implementation to "violate" the spec and removed the 302 redirect without user interaction

I will keep you updated
activities.markdown_message:
couple of little updates:

  • this very issue has been discussed in the IETF 91 meeting , see bottom part of http://www.ietf.org/proceedings/91/minutes/minutes-91-oauth. The outcome seems to be that some kind of security write up should cover this point.
  • I have been contacting OAuth providers and some of that changed the implementation to "violate" the spec and removed the 302 redirect without user interaction

I will keep you updated

activities.message:
this issue is tracked in the planned work for the OAuth working group in  2015, see https://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/oauth/current/msg14047.html

Quoting:

Finally, there is the open redirect Antonio raised in
http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/oauth/current/msg13367.html. The
attack might be difficult to understand but it is still worthwhile
to make an attempt to explain it to a wider audience (and also the
mitigation technique). I believe a draft would be quite suitable for
this purpose and I have spoken with Antonio about it already.

@arice WDYT?
activities.markdown_message:

attack might be difficult to understand but it is still worthwhile
to make an attempt to explain it to a wider audience (and also the
mitigation technique). I believe a draft would be quite suitable for
this purpose and I have spoken with Antonio about it already.

@arice WDYT?

activities.message:
further update.

We and two of the OAuth working group members drafted the version 00 of an OAuth security addendum in [0]

@arice You have asked "Have you identified any provider implementations where the impact went beyond an open redirect? (e.g., leaking tokens or other identifiers through the redirect referrer)"

Once I have reported the issue on the OAuth mailing list, one of the draft coauthor and OAuth Working Group member (John Bradley) has identified a way to use the open redirect to hijack an access token. This is described in "Section 2.2.  Security Compromise: The Authorization Server As Open Redirector"  [1]

@arice any thoughts :) ?

[0] http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-oauth-sanso-open-redirector-00
[1] http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-oauth-sanso-open-redirector-00#page-4

This is described in "Section 2.2. Security Compromise: The Authorization Server As Open Redirector" [1]

[1] http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-oauth-sanso-open-redirector-00#page-4
link to the new draft https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-bradley-oauth-open-redirector-00.txt

activities.message: This helps a lot. Thanks for taking the extra step of collaborating on an update to the RFC. I'll propose this to the panel for a bounty.
activities.markdown_message: This helps a lot. Thanks for taking the extra step of collaborating on an update to the RFC. I'll propose this to the panel for a bounty.

activities.message: @arice out of curiosity, have you got any feedback from the panel :) ?
activities.markdown_message: @arice out of curiosity, have you got any feedback from the panel :) ?

activities.message:
little updates.

* updated draft https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-bradley-oauth-open-redirector-01.txt
* Minutes for the last F2F IETF meeting http://www.ietf.org/proceedings/92/minutes/minutes-92-oauth
Quoting

"Open Redirectors 
Leaks  information in the fragment and referrer, this applies to all protocols that use redirects 
Some of the mitigations
              Append fragments to all redirects
              Internal redirect
              Append content-security-policy Header
              Include Referrer meta tag
So do we do something specific in OAUTH like put this into the security document

Suggestion to update the OAuth Thread document to include these types of recommendations. No decision made."
activities.markdown_message:
little updates.

  • updated draft https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-bradley-oauth-open-redirector-01.txt
  • Minutes for the last F2F IETF meeting http://www.ietf.org/proceedings/92/minutes/minutes-92-oauth Quoting

"Open Redirectors
Leaks information in the fragment and referrer, this applies to all protocols that use redirects
Some of the mitigations
Append fragments to all redirects
Internal redirect
Append content-security-policy Header
Include Referrer meta tag
So do we do something specific in OAUTH like put this into the security document

Suggestion to update the OAuth Thread document to include these types of recommendations. No decision made."

activities.message: Despite being rather widespread, we had a hard time assessing this issue given that the exact implications are not uniform across all providers. Thanks for the patience!
activities.markdown_message: Despite being rather widespread, we had a hard time assessing this issue given that the exact implications are not uniform across all providers. Thanks for the patience!

vulnerability_information_html:
OAuth Providers (servers) that strictly follow rfc6749 are vulnerable to open redirect.
Let me explain, reading [0]

If the request fails due to a missing, invalid, or mismatching
redirection URI, or if the client identifier is missing or invalid,
the authorization server SHOULD inform the resource owner of the
error and MUST NOT automatically redirect the user-agent to the
invalid redirection URI.

If the resource owner denies the access request or if the request
fails for reasons other than a missing or invalid redirection URI,
the authorization server informs the client by adding the following
parameters to the query component of the redirection URI using the
"application/x-www-form-urlencoded" format, per Appendix B:

Now let’s assume this.
I am registering a new client to the victim.com provider.
I register redirect uri attacker.com.

According to [0] if I pass e.g. the wrong scope I am redirected back to attacker.com.
Namely I prepare a url that is in this form:

http://victim.com/authorize?response_type=code&client_id=bc88FitX1298KPj2WS259BBMa9_KCfL3&scope=WRONG_SCOPE&redirect_uri=http://attacker.com

and this is works as an open redirector.
Of course in the positive case if all the parameters are fine this doesn’t apply since the resource owner MUST approve the app via the consent screen (at least once).

I have notified also this issue to the OAuth mailing list.

See also http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/oauth/current/msg13367.html
and http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/oauth/current/maillist.html.
The consensus seems to be that some of the OAuth family spec should be updated... (currently under discussion)

A solution would be to return error 400 rather than redirect to the redirect URI or always show the consent screen (at least once until the app is accepted by the user) even in case of wrong parameter rather than redirect...

[0] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.1.2.1
vulnerability_information:
OAuth Providers (servers) that strictly follow rfc6749 are vulnerable to open redirect.
Let me explain, reading [0]

If the request fails due to a missing, invalid, or mismatching
   redirection URI, or if the client identifier is missing or invalid,
   the authorization server SHOULD inform the resource owner of the
   error and MUST NOT automatically redirect the user-agent to the
   invalid redirection URI.

   If the resource owner denies the access request or if the request
   fails for reasons other than a missing or invalid redirection URI,
   the authorization server informs the client by adding the following
   parameters to the query component of the redirection URI using the
   "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" format, per Appendix B:

Now let’s assume this.
I am registering a new client to the victim.com provider. 
I register redirect uri attacker.com.

According to [0] if I pass e.g. the wrong scope I am redirected back to attacker.com.
Namely I prepare a url that is in this form:

http://victim.com/authorize?response_type=code&client_id=bc88FitX1298KPj2WS259BBMa9_KCfL3&scope=WRONG_SCOPE&redirect_uri=http://attacker.com

and this is works as an open redirector.
Of course in the positive case if all the parameters are fine this doesn’t apply since the resource owner MUST approve the app via the consent screen (at least once).

I have notified also this issue to the OAuth mailing list.

See also http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/oauth/current/msg13367.html
and http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/oauth/current/maillist.html.
The consensus seems to be that some of the OAuth family spec should be updated... (currently under discussion)

A solution would be to return error 400 rather than redirect to the redirect URI or always show the consent screen (at least once until the app is accepted by the user) even in case of wrong parameter rather than redirect...

[0] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.1.2.1
